quoteFirst: I thought I should soon be finished, so went on to the end. A few minutes later, as it appeared, the clock struck again, and I counted 4. Alarmed, I rushed off--vexed that I should get in by half-past 4 instead of
quoteLast: , as I intended--and finished the thing in the train. I got to the _Academy_, and was struck all of a heap.
title: The Life of Francis Thompson
author: Meynell, Everard, 1882-1926

quoteFirst: In that case I was angry because I was visiting the schools—the same over which Sir Bampfylde Fuller resigned—and it seemed to me unfit that the schoolboys should see our Government’s habit of espionage thus illustrated before their faces. But at another place where I arrived in the cold of
quoteLast: in the morning, and found that the telegram to prepare for my arrival had been detained, there was no alloy in the pleasure with which I seized upon the spy detailed to dog me, and compelled him to procure a cart, conduct me to the house where he knew I ought to have been expected, and knock up the sleeping servants to receive me.
title: The new spirit in India
author: Nevinson, Henry Woodd, 1856-1941

quoteFirst: Three nights after his last conference with the Hollanders, Maurice quietly ordered a force of regular troops in Utrecht to be under arms at
quoteLast: o'clock next morning.  About 1000 infantry, including companies of Ernest of Nassau's command at Arnhem and of Brederode's from Vianen, besides a portion of the regular garrison of the place, had accordingly been assembled without beat of drum, before half past three in the morning, and were now drawn up on the market-place or Neu.  At break of day the Prince himself appeared on horseback surrounded by his staff on the Neu or Neude, a large, long, irregular square into which the seven or eight principal streets and thoroughfares of the town emptied themselves.
title: Life and Death of John of Barneveld, Advocate of Holland : with a view of the primary causes and movements of the Thirty Years' War, 1618
author: Motley, John Lothrop, 1814-1877

quoteFirst: If you wish to attend our council [about the alterations in "Fidelio"], I beg to inform you that it assembles this afternoon at
quoteLast: o'clock, in the Spielmann Haus, auf dem Graben, No. 188, 4th Etage, at Herr Weinmüller's. I shall be very glad if you have leisure to be present.
title: Beethoven's Letters 1790-1826, Volume 1
author: Beethoven, Ludwig van, 1770-1827; Köchel, Ludwig Ritter von, 1800-1877 [Compiler]; Nohl, Ludwig, 1831-1885 [Compiler]; Wallace, Grace, Lady, 1804-1878 [Translator]

quoteFirst: The party remained in camp until
quoteLast: on the 27th, owing to a blizzard with heavy snow. Then they made a start in clearer weather and got through the crevassed area before camping at 7 p.m. Joyce was suffering from snow-blindness.
title: South: The Story of Shackleton's Last Expedition, 1914-1917
author: Shackleton, Ernest Henry, Sir, 1874-1922

quoteFirst: But at
quoteLast: he saw clearly that his intended course was wrong, that he should defend himself and speak the truth: that his silence was working greater ill than good.
title: Held to Answer: A Novel
author: MacFarlane, Peter Clark, 1871-1924; King, W. B. [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: Throughout the night the young man who had tasted the wine was seized with violent spasms of nervous shivering, which did not give him a moment's rest; he complained to his companion several times that he could not keep himself still. Towards two o'clock, he had fits of colic and, at daybreak, about
quoteLast: in the morning, he said he did not think he would be able to get up, that his feet were on fire and that he could not possibly put on his boots. The other young man said he would take a turn in the park, and recommended his friend to try and sleep in the meantime.
title: My Memoirs, Vol. II, 1822 to 1825
author: Dumas, Alexandre, 1802-1870; Waller, E. M. (Emily Mary) [Translator]

quoteFirst: By
quoteLast: we had descended so far in the gorge of Chu lonkyok that patches of grass showed here and there amidst the snow, and I saw an alpine shrub called upala, [29] with large pink leaves at the top like those of the water-lily, waved in the wind, which had again begun to blow.
title: Journey to Lhasa and Central Tibet
author: Das, Sarat Chandra, 1849-1917; Rockhill, William Woodville, 1854-1914 [Editor]

quoteFirst: (_Looks at his watch._) Ah, that's five minutes fast. Mrs. Ben Dixon's rather late though. She said she'd be here at
title: The Prude's Progress: A Comedy in Three Acts
author: Jerome, Jerome K. (Jerome Klapka), 1859-1927; Phillpotts, Eden, 1862-1960

quoteFirst: At last, at
quoteLast: , the troops came down and took their places; and at a quarter to four the whole of the guns and rockets opened a tremendous fire to cover the advance; and the 33d, preceded by a small band of Engineers and Sappers under Major Pritchard, and followed by the 45th, advanced to the assault, the 4th and the rest of the first brigade retaining their places as a reserve.
title: The March to Magdala
author: Henty, G. A. (George Alfred), 1832-1902

quoteFirst: Directly the intimation was conveyed that the tow could be attempted, there was a scene of indescribable activity and bustle in the Bremerhaven dock, where the caisson was moored. Full steam was raised on the tugs, and at
quoteLast: in the morning of May 26 the mighty steel barrel moved out of the dock. The towing ropes were hitched on, and very slowly the “Colossus,” as the caisson was named, moved down the harbour, accompanied by the whole fleet of nine vessels engaged in construction work, so that the procession was imposing.
title: Lightships and Lighthouses
author: Talbot, Frederick Arthur Ambrose, 1880-1924

quoteFirst: "They promised to be down at
quoteLast: ," responded the old tar; "and you see it is scarcely that yet; but we must wait no longer. Tom," continued he, addressing his son, a fine young man of five-and-twenty, "run up, my boy, and see if they aren't coming yet.
title: Wilson's Tales of the Borders and of Scotland, Volume 20
author: Wilson, John Mackay, 1804-1835 [Compiler]; Leighton, Alexander, 1800-1874 [Editor]

quoteFirst: Passing on, then, to the incident of her sudden flight from her home, when she heard of L’Angelier’s death, the Dean repudiated the notion that she was absconding from justice. She had left Glasgow early in the morning, and at
quoteLast: was found on board a steamer going from Greenock to Helensburgh. Any one going by rail could easily have overtaken her.
title:
Reports of Trials for Murder by Poisoning;
by Prussic Acid, Strychnia, Antimony, Arsenic, and Aconita. Including the trials of Tawell, W. Palmer, Dove, Madeline Smith, Dr. Pritchard, Smethurst, and Dr. Lamson, with chemical introduction and notes on the poisons used
author: Browne, G. Lathom (George Lathom), 1815-1892; Stewart, C. G. (Charles G.), active 19th century

quoteFirst: (_Looks at his watch._) Ah, that's five minutes fast. Mrs. Ben Dixon's rather late though. She said she'd be here at
title: The Prude's Progress: A Comedy in Three Acts
author: Jerome, Jerome K. (Jerome Klapka), 1859-1927; Phillpotts, Eden, 1862-1960

quoteFirst: There is something inexpressibly beautiful in the unused day, something beautiful in the fact that it is still untouched, unsoiled; and town and country share alike in this loveliness. At
quoteLast: on a June morning even London has not assumed her responsibilities, but smiles and glows lighthearted and smokeless under the caresses of the morning sun.
title: The Roadmender
author: Fairless, Michael, 1869-1901; Taylor, Will F. [Illustrator]

quoteFirst: The next morning at eight the Clifton, followed soon after by the other gunboats and the transports, crossed the bar and anchored inside about two miles from the fort. At
quoteLast: the Clifton, Sachem, and Arizona advanced to attack the works. At four the Sachem received a shot in her boilers and was at once enveloped in steam.
title:
The Gulf and Inland Waters
The Navy in the Civil War. Volume 3.
author: Mahan, A. T. (Alfred Thayer), 1840-1914

quoteFirst: The hearse, which was drawn by four horses and was accompanied by his servants and by priests, arrived at the capital at
quoteLast: in the morning. Great numbers of country people followed his coffin weeping.
title: Ludwig the Second, King of Bavaria
author: Tschudi, Clara, 1856-1945; Hearn, Ethel Harriet [Translator]

quoteFirst: Three nights after his last conference with the Hollanders, Maurice quietly ordered a force of regular troops in Utrecht to be under arms at
quoteLast: o'clock next morning.  About 1000 infantry, including companies of Ernest of Nassau's command at Arnhem and of Brederode's from Vianen, besides a portion of the regular garrison of the place, had accordingly been assembled without beat of drum, before half past three in the morning, and were now drawn up on the market-place or Neu.  At break of day the Prince himself appeared on horseback surrounded by his staff on the Neu or Neude, a large, long, irregular square into which the seven or eight principal streets and thoroughfares of the town emptied themselves.

quoteFirst: The inner, of very small dimensions, has a low barrel vaulting borne by arches with primitive twelfth-century figures. The _sanctum sanctorum_ is slightly raised, and from this inmost Holy of Holies the relics are shown to the devout who kneel in front of a low railing every day at 8.30 A.M. and
quoteLast: The cedar wood _arca_ in which they are kept is of Byzantine workmanship. The relics include some of Mary Magdalene's hair, and crumbs left over from the feeding of the five thousand.
title: Cathedral Cities of Spain
author: Collins, W. W. (William Wiehe), 1862-1951

quoteFirst: As Suva lay 18° 22', I was sure I could hold the wind through the Passage, if I could keep away from the uncharted coral reefs which are so dangerous to navigation among those islands. At
quoteLast: in the morning Broken-Nosed Pete sang out from the foretop, "A light on the port bow." I took the binoculars and ran up the mizzen-rigging. There was the long-looked-for light.
title: The Flying Bo'sun: A Mystery of the Sea
author: Mason, Arthur, 1876-1955
